content: all right so as I've made it obnoxiously clear I've gotten into wargaming
recently I looked into Warhammer 40k it seemed inaccessible to me both the price
of the books the complexity of the rules the needless complexity and the price of
the models just seemed prohibitive so I gave up but then I don't I don't
remember where but googling or something I found one page 40k which is a one-page
condensation of the rules that I think it's one individual or maybe a small
team have put together it's not official it's not sanctioned by Games Workshop
it's free but it has a huge following and is generally it seems to be regarded
as very well done and from my experience with kings of war in reading through the
rules I would agree so I've really gotten into
it and built a couple armies one of them is the necrons
so here is a miniature which was inspired by and is similar to an
annihilation barge but is definitely not an annihilation barge
I started with double corrugated
cardboard and set my compass to five centimetres so as to draw a 10
centimeter circle draw a line through the center point then I set my compass
to three and a half centimeters in order to draw a seven centimeter circle which
touches the side of the larger one you achieve this by placing the needle on
the line three and a half centimeters away from the perimeter cut out the
smaller circle first using your crafting knife this will be a royal pain be
patient and do it in eight to ten passes of the knife now I'm not sure the most
eloquent way to describe this next part but look at what I'm doing here draw
straight lines from the two most extreme points of the small circle tangentially
you can see that this creates sort of a crescent shape out of the remains of a
larger circle that's the final piece that you want to cut out apply
corrugation cladding as we've done many times before just hot glue on some same
cardstock we'll refer to this as shape a going forward now draw another ten
centimeter diameter circle and again draw a line through the center then sent
your compass to four centimeters and plant the needle a half centimeter away
from the original center and draw the circle then draw two straight lines as
you see here this shaded portion is the piece that we want we'll call this shape
be going forward here's a wood bit from an assorted package you can get from the
crafting store makes a good mounting point hot glue it to one side of shape a
here's another wood bit just a circular wooden disc gonna hot glue this to the
other side of shape a so that it's mostly hanging off the back edge and
then to that we will hot glue on shape thee as you see here and finally I took
another one of those mounting points and hot glued it on the top let's put that
assembly aside for now look through your bead collection and find some that are
sort of gear and barrel shaped so first I took these two tiny ones and stuck a
toothpick into them and chop them down to length about a quarter inch sticking
out then I hot glued those radially to a large cylindrical bead then I took a
kebab skewer cut it to about two and a half inches and hot glue on that big
bead plus two other gear shaped ones on either side of it at the far end of the
skewer lastly I hot glued some other bead on to the other end of the skewer
this is the output end of the gun make two of these guns and then hot glue them
to a one-inch metal washer as you see here eventually this washer will be
attached to the mounting point on the barge but do not attach it yet
so next thing I did was cut some chipboard rectangles about a half inch
wide and scored them so that they'd crease easily and hot glue them into
place on to shape B and the wooden disk as you see here this helps to reinforce
shape B's connection to the overall assembly now build the lower gun take
four lengths of kabob skewer bunch them together and hot glue beads onto both
ends then hot glue the whole thing to the underside mounting point as shown
now I cut two pieces of chipboard and hot glue them to the underside at the
tips of the Crescent these are platforms upon which you could place miniatures
later to represent the pilots now back to the main guns base it in black except
for the kabob skewers which you base in white apply metallic gunmetal gray to
everything that is black and apply neon green to the white barrels let that dry
and then apply a black wash to the silver bits just load up your brush with
heavy water and pull out a little bit of black paint and swirl it around on the
paper to check the thinness you'll see that it flows nicely into all the nooks
and crannies next thing I did was cut a bunch of
chipboard shapes and just hot glue them to the assembly talking about these
white bits that you see here I didn't sweat dimensions just eyeball
them and once you cut one trace it so you get a duplicate for the other side
base in black apply gunmetal to the mounting point and the lower gun
now take that neon green again and edge highlight all the edges on the piece
just load up the brush as if you were going to dry brush and Nick at the edges
all the way around this will take a little while I used a very fine brush to
paint on some arcane symbols with white PVA glue then I dumped on fine gold
glitter after that dries completely brush off the excess glitter
and then I coated all of the non silver
surfaces with a matte varnish to seal in the glitter and keep the look consistent
finally hot glue the main guns to the mounting point and then attach the
entire thing to your sixty millimeter base
I made my base with my 3d printer but chipboard works just as well so here she
is completed I apologize I don't have any Necron pilots made yet but they
would stand on those platforms there so the guns came out nicely this is a
flying unit so I just mounted it on some ornate bead under there well I forgot to
mention earlier for shape B I did end up chopping off the tip of it to make it
flat and I mounted a Swarovski crystal there just a little bit more arcane neck
Cranitch whatever so again this is on a 60 millimeter base in accordance with
the rules I am fairly happy with how this turned out it's very close to the
the model upon which it was based or inspired in terms of size here's a
fantasy orc just for scale for comparison though it's a big unit
so I am wild Locke thank you for joining
me and I'll see you next time
